--- IS_Claim_01_01 ---
IDA Belt is a customer service representative for Succeed Insurance. This demonstration reviews the basic functionality available to her in ClaimCenter. The first thing IDA does every day is log in to ClaimCenter. IDA is taken to the Claim Search screen when she logs in. As a CSR, she can see three tabs on the opening page, Claim, Search, and Address Book. In this scenario, IDA has never navigated to a claim. IDA is taken to the simple search screen for claims. When she clicks the Claim tab, the system takes her directly to a No Claim screen. From here, she can either create a new claim, or navigate to the Claim Search. If IDA had navigated to a claim previously, this screen would show her the last claim she was working on. IDA is where IDA can go to search for claims. When she clicks the Search tab, she is taken to the Simple Search screen for claims. When she clicks the Search drop-down, she sees that there are several options from which to choose. She can search for claims, activities, checks, recoveries, or bulk invoices. IDA decides to perform a simple claim search. She can use this page to search using a claim number, a policy number, or names of anyone listed on a claim. IDA needs to search for any claims that involve Ray Newton. Since she wants to see all claims where Ray Newton has any involvement, she selects any party involved. Then she enters Newt as the last name. And clicks Search. The results show all the claims where Ray Newton is involved. Ray is involved in two claims, one where he is the sole claimant, and one where he is one of several claimants. Another search option is called Search by Contact. This search uses a free text search engine which allows for searches on partial names, phonetic names, or sounds like names. She is unsure how Ray Newton spells his name, so she enters Newt on. And clicks Search. Although she misspelled Newton, the search returns results with any claim with the name Newton. The name field searches for the contents in the first name or last name. She is now looking for claims with the name Frank. She isn't sure of the spelling, and enters F-R-A-I-N-K as the name. She clicks Search. Again, even though the spelling doesn't match, the results show all claims which include any party with the name Frank. The advanced search page includes more search criteria. Such as assigned group, assigned user, jurisdiction, claim status, and more. Claim Center also allows users to search for vendors which are maintained in the address book, or contact manager. Aida needs to find information about a specific vendor. She knows the name starts with A-B but isn't sure of the rest. She enters A-B as the name, last name. And clicks Search. The result of the search shows A-B construction, which is a vendor maintained in the address book. This is the end of the Customer Service Representative Basics demonstration. IDA is already logged into ClaimCenter. She gets a call from Mr. Henderson who wants to report an auto accident he had today. IDA will use the new claim wizard to create an auto claim. She uses the claim tab. To navigate to the new claim screen where she can create a claim. IDA enters part of Mr. Henderson's name as the search criteria. She searches for Mr. Henderson's policy. If multiple policies had matched the claim, criteria that IDA entered, she would see a list of policies in the middle of the screen. Mark describes the damage that was done to his vehicle. IDA uses the vehicle menu button to edit the vehicle information. IDA enters the description of the damage. The only detail is that there is severe damage to the right side of the car. IDA is the vehicle. Since that is the only detail that Mr. Henderson has, IDA saves her changes. She clicks OK once more to save the vehicle details. She is now done with the claim details and clicks next to move to services. Mark tells IDA that he needs help finding an auto body shop to repair his car. On the services screen, IDA begins a search for a repair shop. She checks the box for a body shop. She wants to search for a convenient body shop, so she clicks the menu button to begin the search. She selects search. On the search screen, she narrows the search by limiting the type of service Mark needs, which is auto body. She enters San Mateo as the city. She searches for a vendor. The search results show that MB Garage is in San Mateo, so she clicks select. IDA uses the drop-down on the service address to select a convenient service location for Mark. That is the only service that Ida needs to arrange for now, so she continues to the final new claim wizard step. Ida is using the automated assignment rules to assign this claim, so she clicks Finish to complete the new claim wizard and assign the claim to an adjuster. As the last step, she tells Mark that his claim was assigned to Chris Craft, and that the adjuster will be in touch soon. As part of adjudication, an adjuster reviews the claims exposures to make decisions about damage. These decisions may include making payments for the claim. Chris is still logged into ClaimCenter. He selects the Mark Henderson claim. Chris needs to evaluate the cost of repairing Mr. Henderson's vehicle in terms of the value of the vehicle. If the repair costs are more than the car is worth, Succeed will just pay the value of the car. There is a total loss calculator function in ClaimCenter. The adjuster can use it to figure out how to proceed with this claim. Since the total loss calculator is related to an exposure, Chris starts by opening the exposures screen. He sees an exposure for Mark's vehicle, so he opens it to look at the details. He opens the total loss calculator. He clicks edit to make changes to the exposure. Chris knows that the vehicle is over 10 years old. And has over 100,000 miles. Mark, also told him that an extrication was required to remove him from the vehicle. He clicks, update, to save his changes and to see if the vehicle is a total loss. He sees that the calculator has qualified the vehicle as a total loss. Because the vehicle is considered a total loss, a new tab for vehicle salvage appears on the exposure. Chris goes to the claim work plan to see if anything has changed. He sees that there are two new activities, recover vehicle, and salvage vehicle. Moving forward on claim adjudication, Chris needs to make a payment against this exposure. He adds a check using the actions menu. He expected to simply issue a check to Mr. Henderson, but there are validation errors that must be fixed before he can continue. Claim Center uses validation levels to identify the maturity of a claim and its exposures. The claim and exposure are currently at the lowest validation level, new loss completion. This is fine for the early stages of adjudication, but in order to make payments, Claim Center requires that the claim and exposure be at the ability to pay validation level. Claim Center uses rules to identify validation, issues and set the validation level. The first, error states that in California, the insured driver's license number is required to make a payment. To correct the data, Chris clicks on the error to open the parties involved screen. He then selects Mark Henderson. He opens the contact details. The driver's license details are at the bottom of the screen, so he scrolls down on the page. The field in error is highlighted in red. Chris enters the driver's license number. He then selects California as the state. He scrolls up the page. And clicks Update. Chris then clears the error message. He has corrected the errors, but just to make sure, he uses the validation option to check that the claim and exposure, are at ability to pay. He sees that there are no errors, so he can proceed with issuing a check. He clears the validation results to close the worksheet. Just as before, he uses the actions menu to create a check. Since this payment is for Mark's vehicle, the payee is Mark Henderson. Chris continues to the next step of the check wizard. The payment is for Mark's vehicle, so Chris chooses first party vehicle, claim cost, auto body, as the reserve line for this payment. This is a partial payment. Chris enters $4,700 for the payment amount and applies the deductible. He continues to the last step. After reviewing the payment details, Chris creates the check. He notices that the check status is pending approval. Chris goes to the work plan. An activity has been added for his supervisor to approve the payment. Chris is done with this claim for now, so he logs out of claim center. This is the end of the exposures and financials demonstration. Part of Sue's job as a supervisor is to make sure that claims are processed as quickly as possible. Sometimes, she needs to reassign a claim from one adjuster to another, because of the adjuster's workload or other circumstances. She clicks the Team tab to see the workloads of her team members. The summary screen shows aggregated counts of the work assigned to her team. If she supervised multiple teams, it would show them all. Sue decides to reassign the bill. Sue decides to reassign the bill Kinman claim to Dan Henson to reduce Andy's workload. She selects the bill Kinman claim by clicking the checkbox to the left of the claim. Then she clicks, Assign. On the Assign screen, she selects Dan Henson from the Select from List Assignment drop-down. And clicks Assign. After Sue Reassign. This ends the supervisor reassign a claim demonstration.

In this demonstration, Ida Belt, a customer service representative, receives calls from a vendor and two clients asking her to check on something specific about a claim in which they have an interest. Mr. Smith at the garage needs to know which adjuster is assigned to the callers. Andy Applegate is an adjuster with Succeed Insurance. In this demonstration, he sees that he has an urgent, activity to call Mr. Farley, an insurance customer. He reviews the policy and the notes on the claim to re-familiarize himself with the claim. Andy logs into ClaimCenter. When Andy signs into ClaimCenter, the first page he sees is the desktop activities page. Although most of the adjusters use the activity to call Mr. Farley, an insurance customer. The second page is the default, the first page is the default. He has decided to call Mr. Farley, an insurance customer. He opens his preferences from the actions menu to change his startup view to desktop claims. Andy selects desktop claims as his new startup view. He then clicks Update to save the changes. For the changes to take effect, he needs to log out and log back in. Andy logs back into ClaimCenter. Now he sees his assigned claims as soon as he logs in. He reviews the claims and sees that there are no new claims assigned to him since yesterday. Now he looks at the activities page to see what activities are on his list of tasks to complete. One of the key pieces of information about an activity is the name of the insured. In the default tabular view, the insured column is in the middle, and Andy wants it to be closer to the beginning of the view. He drags the insured column and drops it just before the due date column. Notice that the insured column now appears to the left of the due date column. Just to make sure that he doesn't have any activities that he needs to prepare for, Andy changes the activities filter to all open. Andy notices that there is an urgent activity to call the insured, Mr. Farley, scheduled for tomorrow. He has some time, so he decides to make the call now. Andy wants to make sure he is familiar with the claim before he makes the call, so he opens the claim by clicking the claim number in the activity. Andy scrolls down the page to see the notes on the summary page. He looks at the notes on the summary page, and now he remembers Mr. Farley. He realizes that Mr. Farley is probably trying to get the status on his vehicle. Andy scrolls back to the top of the summary page. He notices that the icon next to the document name means that the document is not stored in the system, but rather is a reference to an external document. He clicks the information icon to see details about the document. Andy sees that the document is an auto repair estimate, or a quote, and that the document is not stored on the server. It is a paper document that is stored in a physical location like a file cabinet. He finds and looks at the actual document. Once he reviews the document, he decides to approve the quote. He starts by navigating back to the summary screen. He then clicks Approve Quote on the service. He checks the amount on the latest quote and sees that it is correct, so he approves the quote. He accepts the proposed requested service completion date. After he approves the quote, Andy sees that the next action is finish the work. There are no other actions required on the claim at this time. This ends the check work plan and documents demonstration.

Once vendor services are created, an adjuster can manage those services. For example, he can track the exact status of a service, is it waiting for a quote, waiting to be completed, waiting for payment, and so on, the adjuster can update the status of a service based on information he receives from the vendor. If the ClaimCenter vendor was using a vendor portal, much of this management would happen through the portal. However, in this example, the adjuster enters quotes and invoices, and marks services as complete directly in ClaimCenter. There are two services on this claim. A towing service, which is perform service only, and a repair service, which is quote and perform service. Andy hears from Bills that they have accepted the work for towing Mr. Williams' truck. He starts by clicking the towing service. He sets the vendor progress to vendor accepted work. He accepts the default for the expected service completion date, and clicks update to save the changes. Some time later, Andy talks to Bills again and finds out that they have also accepted the auto body work. He clicks the repair service. Just as he did for the towing service, he sets the vendor progress to vendor accepted work. He accepts the default for the expected service completion date, and clicks update to save the changes. Now that both services have been accepted by the vendor, the work may begin. The next, action for the towing service is finish the work. The next, action for the repair service is add quote. After some time has passed, the work is completed for the towing service. And he clicks the towing service. He sets the vendor progress to vendor completed work. He also received an invoice for the towing service, so he clicks add invoice. He enters the description for the invoice. The invoice has only one line item, and it is for towing. The description for the line item is towing for Mr. Williams' truck to the shop. And the amount is $250. With all of the invoice information entered, Andy clicks update to save the invoice. Adding the invoice creates options in the details section to either pay, mark as paid, or withdraw the invoice. Straight through invoice processing is enabled in the base configuration, but Claim Center could not determine which reserve line to use for the payment, so it did not automatically pay this invoice. Andy chooses to pay the invoice. Paying the invoice opens the payment wizard with most of the fields completed. Andy verifies the basic information and moves to enter the payment information. He chooses the first party vehicle. Claim cost slash auto body reserve line. And sets the payment type to partial. The amount of the payment was completed automatically from the invoice, so he clicks next to continue. On this screen, Andy reviews the payment information. He sees there is a $70 deduction, and wants to find out what this is for. The deduction is for backup withholding. This is because the vendor's tax information has either not been supplied or has not been verified. And he clicks OK to return to the check instructions. The details look correct, so he clicks Finish to complete the payment. He also received the quote for the repair of Mr. Williams' truck. He clicks the Repair Service. And clicks the Details tab. He is adding the quote that he received from Bill's Quick Auto Repair, so he clicks, Add Quote. The quote says that it should take 15 days to complete the repairs. He adds the description of the quote. He adds the category, Labor, a description of the line item, and the amount of the first line item. The quote has two line items. One for labor, the other for parts. Andy adds a second line item for parts. He sets the category to parts, enters the description, and enters the amount of $400 for parts. With all the information from the quote, entered, he clicks, Update to save the quote. After the quote is entered, Andy can approve the quote. The actions he can take are Approve Quote, Request a Requote, or Revise the quote. Andy thinks the quote is in line with what was expected for the repairs, so he approves the quote. He accepts the default requested service completion date, and clicks Update. The process of entering the quote and the invoices, and marking a service as complete, all affect the vendor metrics. These metrics help monitor the effectiveness of a vendor. For example, if on the quote, they reported the work could be completed in 5 days, but it took 20 days, that would be reflected in the metrics. Bill's quick auto repair sent Andy an invoice for the repairs along with a note that the work is completed. Andy first sets the vendor progress to vendor completed work. Andy sees that the next, action changes to add invoice. He clicks add invoice to start the process. Andy enters the description of the invoice. The first line item on the invoice is for labor. He adds the description, and sets the amount to $500. He clicks, add, to create a new line item. This line item is for parts. He enters the description and sets the amount to $400. Andy checks that the line items match the invoice and that the total is correct. With that verified, he clicks Update to save the invoice. The invoice creation, automatically triggered creation of a check, because Claim Center could correlate the invoice with a reserve line. The next, action for the repair is now none, invoices paid. Andy logs out of Claim Center. This ends the managing services demonstration.
